displayed_text: Patient: That’d be fine. (Pause30sec) Doctor: Um, I can let the study team know that you’re potentially interested. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: So, they know that we’re, somebody’s out there who wants it, but you have to, you know, let us know that that’s what you want to do. Patient: Okay. So, it looks like there’s gonna be thirty-six, um, patients on this. Doctor: So, right now, I think three people are there currently. There’s one more spot available. Patient: In group one. Doctor: I don’t know if it’s group one; I heard group two. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Um. And then once those three have been treated, then, they’ll open up again for three more people. Patient: Okay. How often do you do that? Doctor: Uh, you have to be on drug for at least about, the third person should be on at least a month, and it all has to be deemed safe, and then the next three people.

Family Member: Oh. Doctor: And prostate’s the only one that this is true. Family Member: It’s the only one? Doctor: Now, we are going to move on to those kinds of treatments, but, so far, those ones have not been as successful as it is in other treatments, in other diseases. Family Member: Yeah. Okay. Okay. Doctor: That’s where we’re at. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So you know all of this is, one, you have to be okeydokey with the plan. Two, there’s no emergency, but I always like to stay ahead of your cancer. Family Member: Ahead of the game. Yeah. Doctor: So that’s why we’re having this discussion. Hum, and, three, you know, you don’t like this, then we move onto pills. You know? And there I have different trials, different options, and things like that. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just that I always like to try to get this one in.

Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing? Doctor: Yeah. Like, but if you’re fifty. That’s not in line with what I think is happening. You should level off with this stuff. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: It should come back down to like a seven or eight or whatever? Doctor: Yeah. Or even if it stays ten forever. I don’t care. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But I don’t want it to go to a hundred because then I’d feel like, uh-oh, maybe somethings going on. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? We, we have a look now which is not a super early look but it still is within, you know, a few weeks of finishing. Sometimes when times goes on, then, you know, you’ll have new stuff, but- Family Member: So no, no, no, uh, MRIs in order right now? Doctor: No. Unless you’re telling me you’re worse. Family Member: Well, he’s got, he’s in pain, but that might be sciatic. He don’t know. Patient: No.

Family Member: Yeah. Today he gets- he gets his next Lupron February twelfth. Doctor: Okay. And what about the (Xgeva) Family Member: Uh-uh. Doctor: That may be helpful. So I’ll, uh, send a note to her. There is a bone-strengthening medication. Family Member: He’s seen a, uh, do you need to see your dentist before you-? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. That kind of stuff. But, uh, but it can be very helpful, especially because the hormone therapy all this time has, can weaken the bones. So, so this may be something that will help, uh, and sometimes it can help with the bone pain, too, uh. You know? So I think all around it’s a good idea to get that started. Family Member: So continue with the Lupron, and every four months is what she gets us. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So what’s, what’s the deal at the (coughs) Doctor: Well, the trial is done. They are still analyzing the results. So there’s no final results, yet. Patient: From what? Doctor: From the study you were on. Right? That’s what you’re asking?

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: I wanted to have that conversation with you. Patient: Uh hum. Sure. And this is the PSA level; you’re also saying we need to see something on the CT scan, right? Doctor: Correct. So for this particular trial, if the cancer is invisible, which will become non-metastatic. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You would not be eligible. So it just has to do with; this trial is designed for a specific subset of patients so that cancer has to be both metastatic and hormone-resistant. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So in other words invisible and resistant to hormone therapy, and then we basically do the screening procedures and if you pass the screening then we enroll you in the trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But again, I didn’t want to go into a huge amount of detail because it’s a little bit premature. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it would require also that you go back on the Lupron, which I’m not sure that you would want to do that. So just

Patient: trying to do the best I can health wise and… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …and uh uh as far as uh you know relationship-wise uh I I you know I meet people you know ladies and they get to like me, but they won’t to another step then it just seems like my physical part down there they’re trying to come in but they won’t. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And so.. Doctor: Alright. It takes up to a year Patient: I’m still having problems. Doctor: It takes a year generally and your surgery was when August? Patient: Uhh September. Doctor: September and so do you have any flows at all? Patient: Uh no you know it acting like it wanna but never… Doctor: And you’re taking the medicine?

Family Member: I think Patient: And I finished that last night. Doctor: And so did they give you something also for spasms? Patient: No. Doctor: So Oxybutynin. Family Member: Uh well yes, they did but he decided not to take that. Patient: Oh yeah, they said for pain, and I didn’t need that. Doctor: Well that’s for spasm, but they also give you medicine for pain, Hydro-per ; so you can take either of those two medicines. Doctor: So five milligrams Patient: What’s a spasm? Family Member: Spasm. Doctor: Uh your bladder. You feel a cramping down.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: My approach would be as we discussed last time to wait until that PSA level goes above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if we don’t. That may not happen for three months; it may not happen for six months. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: If it continues at the same pace it will probably happen – have the PSA will reach one point zero in the next year. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, I’m not exactly sure when that will happen. But it accelerates and that happens sooner. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: If it continues at the same pace you know if it increases by one or two decimal points, who knows, it may take you know six to nine months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Maybe up to twelve months. So one of the things that I wanted to discuss with both of you today is what we would do if it reached one. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Yeah. That works for me. Doctor: Yeah. Blood work, Aximun scan. You're not on MyChart? Patient: I tried to get on MyChart, but the little number that he sent me, died or whatever. Doctor: Yeah, but I can we can print out a new one for you today. Patient: Okay good. Doctor: And then if you can just MyChart message me your email- Patient: Yes. Doctor: -but as to you know, my Aximun scan is scheduled for this day. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then I can add you in for the following Tuesday. Patient: All right. Sounds good. Doctor: Without knowing when that schedule, there's probably not anybody there. So we'll see what that looks like.

Patient: No, that's a, uh, a wart. I covered up. Doctor: Ok, alright. When did that thing--that wasn't there was it, last time? Patient: Well, it’s when cold weather hits it seems like to grow. Doctor: Oh you see, so you get these any way. Patient: Yeah, I go to the Dermanolog, Dermatologist for it. Doctor: Ok. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright, and uh, I do need to feel your tummy. (Dr. examining patient) Patient: Mm hmm. Doctor: And urine, no problems? Patient: No problems. Doctor: Ok. So should we go back on the chemo?

Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and you know, depending on what your scans show, I actually would favor Provenge, which is the vaccine therapy, because it’s almost like a flu shot. We don’t really know what happens to the PSA but we do know that if you get it in people who get it Patient: Is that a shot or is that through? Doctor: So, here’s where it gets a little complicated. You know, the flu shot is also like a vaccine. That, you know, you just get here. But, in cancer it’s a little bit more complicated. So, what we would do is actually send you to the Red Cross right across the street. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They hook you up to a machine and then they take out your cells so they’re not using my cells or anybody else’s cells. They’re taking out your cells, your immune cells so that when they take it they ship it to Atlanta so if you’ve never been to Atlanta, your cells will be. They wake it up and then they ship it back to me, the like better version of you and then I reinfuse it back to you so that your cells know to find the cancer. That’s the thought of how that medicine works. So, we do that, let’s say the Red Cross on a Monday, I get your stuff back like on a Thursday and then I reinfuse it to you on a Thursday. We do that 3 times and then the treatment is done. It’s self-limited. Okay. Patient: So, that’s your immune system. Doctor: That’s the immune system. Patient: So, what happens in between, does that weaken your immune system or? Doctor: No, it actually if anything strengthens. Patient: I mean while it’s out. Doctor: Oh, no. We don’t take everything out. We just take a few things out. Patient: Oh, okay.

Patient: It’s not quite that. It’s not so bad. Doctor: It’s much less so. Family Member: And there’s no affiliation obviously in Toledo that… Doctor: No. Not – well especially for these studies. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We are under such strict regulations that we can’t even do it in our own satellite in F____. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Leave alone you know in any other place. Family Member: Sure. Doctor: Whatever we can do close to home we can, we do, but most of the stuff is not allowed. You know the FDA just regulates that pretty tightly. Family Member 2: Okay so I guess we’ll just stick with what we’re doing. Doctor: So I think uh, you know think about it. For now we’ve given you the pills but if you decide to come off based if today’s PSA is going higher regardless of the scans, that’s perfectly okay. Nobody is going to be mad at you. You’re allowed to make that decision. And uh…

Family Member: May be an option. Doctor: Because where we’ve been you know we’ve been talking about you know hormones is the base layer and then do we add chemotherapy on top of that? And then we talked to you about the clinical trial – Patient: Right. Doctor: - which is you know potentially adding a third drug on top of it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So three punches versus two punches. Patient: Right. Doctor: Because everybody gets the hormones. Patient: Right. Doctor: And if we decide to do the chemotherapy it’s because we think it’s the right thing for you - Patient: Okay. Doctor: And the clinical trial is just sort of you know on top of that to see whether or not we add an additional medicine. Patient: Okay, so let me ask you a question. So what is the next thing to do?

Patient: Well I guess... Family Member: How long would we have to do that for that just out of curiosity? Doctor: It’s a, I’ll give you the exact… Doctor: Yeah but it’s more for the monitoring and because it’s a phase one trial it’s a little bit more closer monitoring. At least the first few weeks. After that it goes down to once a month once we sort of get the comfort level that you’re tolerating it okay, we know all the PKs and the blood level things are done, then it becomes much easier schedule. Family Member: What are the, how often are you talking about? A couple times a week or? Doctor: Well the first few weeks it will be about once a week or so or once every couple of weeks after a little while. And then after the first couple of months it goes to like I said once every four weeks. Family Member: Kind of like we started with this one. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Because the first couple of weeks I came down here… Doctor: It was more intense and then it… Family Member: In the beginning. Doctor: And then it smooths off once.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 10 years (5 years but le: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 10 years (5 years but less than 10 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we actually have another study which may or may not be open in time which is a pill plus another pill. The pill is Patient: I’m available all day tomorrow. Doctor: Okay. I will have to work with the group to see what they can do to get that. Patient: Or or I can, I can be s - I can be wherever I need to be at like seven o’clock on Wednesday morning. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Patient: Is it - That’s about what, a two hour deal? Doctor: Mm probably longer. I would just spend, I would just block off a half a day because they’re probably gonna put you in that happy place like when you get a colonoscopy happy place. Patient: I am awake during my colonoscopies. I go into twilight. Doctor: You’ll be in twilight, you’ll be in twilight. Patient: Just ‘cause I like to look at the – doctor uh. Doctor: Oh you’re like, you like to actually be awake.
